articles.headline: Guess Who's Got His Back?
articles.snippet: The colossus Wal-Mart, through its Sam's Club division, can be a most unlikely ally of the mom-and-pop store.
articles.abstract: The colossus Wal-Mart, through its Sam's Club division, can be a most unlikely ally of the mom-and-pop store.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIGHT or wrong, it has somehow become conventional wisdom: Wal-Mart is bad for small businesses, outspending, outmaneuvering and outgrowing lesser rivals until they change their strategy or close their doors.

articles.headline: Reality and Fantasy, Indivisible
articles.snippet: Questions of truth, verisimilitude and reality are a substantial part of this year's Tribeca Film Festival, most notably in "American Cannibal: The Road to Reality."
articles.abstract: Questions of truth, verisimilitude and reality are a substantial part of this year's Tribeca Film Festival, most notably in "American Cannibal: The Road to Reality."
articles.lead_paragraph: THIS year's Tribeca Film Festival opened with "United 93," a fictional account of real but mostly unknowable events. The feature film examines the last hour in the lives of the only group of Americans who were able to alter the events of Sept. 11.

articles.headline: The Rise and Fall of Revolution
articles.snippet: Revolution Studios, run by Joe Roth, will close in October 2007, despite predictions that it would soon become profitable.
articles.abstract: Revolution Studios, run by Joe Roth, will close in October 2007, despite predictions that it would soon become profitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, April 29 — For more than a year, Joe Roth has been hearing the Hollywood gossips predict the demise of his six-year-old movie studio, Revolution Studios. Now that they are right, he wants to set the record straight.

articles.headline: New Microsoft Browser Raises Google's Hackles
articles.snippet: Google says Microsoft is unfairly grabbing Web traffic by making its MSN search engine the default in its browser.
articles.abstract: Google says Microsoft is unfairly grabbing Web traffic by making its MSN search engine the default in its browser.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a $10 billion advertising market at stake, Google, the fast-rising Internet star, is raising objections to the way that it says Microsoft, the incumbent powerhouse of computing, is wielding control over Internet searching in its new Web browser.

articles.headline: Deadline Passes Without Darfur Accord
articles.snippet: The talks were extended 48 hours after Sudan's government accepted a peace agreement, but two of Darfur's three main rebel groups raised last-minute objections.
articles.abstract: The talks were extended 48 hours after Sudan's government accepted a peace agreement, but two of Darfur's three main rebel groups raised last-minute objections.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan, Monday, May 1 — Sudan's government offered Sunday to accept a potentially historic Darfur peace agreement, but two of Darfur's three main rebel groups raised last-minute objections that left the negotiations mired in confusion as a midnight deadline passed. Mediators agreed to extend the talks for 48 hours at the request of the United States.
articles.byline: By Lydia Polgreen and Joel Brinkley

articles.headline: A Small Step at Starbucks From Mocha to Movies
articles.snippet: Starbucks is seeking movies and books to promote in the hope of duplicating the success it has had selling and promoting music.
articles.abstract: Starbucks is seeking movies and books to promote in the hope of duplicating the success it has had selling and promoting music.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, April 30 — With barely one movie under its belt, Starbucks is moving aggressively toward expanding its involvement in the entertainment business, seeking movies and books to promote in the hope of duplicating the success it has had with music.

articles.headline: Next Step for Counterfeiters: Faking the Whole Company
articles.snippet: Counterfeiters in China set up a parallel NEC that developed its own products and had links to a network of factories in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan.
articles.abstract: Counterfeiters in China set up a parallel NEC that developed its own products and had links to a network of factories in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — At first it seemed to be nothing more than a routine case of counterfeiting in a country where faking it has become an industry.

articles.headline: Some See Hints of Disharmony in Qaeda Tapes
articles.snippet: The broadcasts last week by three terrorist leaders show the differing motives of Al Qaeda's leadership.
articles.abstract: The broadcasts last week by three terrorist leaders show the differing motives of Al Qaeda's leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 30 — The broadcasts last week by three of the world's best-known terrorist leaders shared at least one common goal, American intelligence officials say. They sought to embarrass the West by showing that the terrorists were still able to communicate with their followers, despite the intensive efforts to capture or kill them and the $25 million bounty that is on each of their heads.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Mock Iraqi Villages in Mojave Prepare Troops for Battle
articles.snippet: The training villages are at the heart of a vast shift in U.S. strategy, from an emphasis on army-to-army battles to preparing for guerrilla insurgencies.
articles.abstract: The training villages are at the heart of a vast shift in U.S. strategy, from an emphasis on army-to-army battles to preparing for guerrilla insurgencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Dexter Filkins and John F. Burns

articles.headline: Sharp Reaction to G.O.P. Plan on Gas Rebate
articles.snippet: A plan to send $100 checks to voters is eliciting more scorn than gratitude.
articles.abstract: A plan to send $100 checks to voters is eliciting more scorn than gratitude.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 30 — The Senate Republican plan to mail $100 checks to voters to ease the burden of high gasoline prices is eliciting more scorn than gratitude from the very people it was intended to help.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Deep in a U.S. Desert, Practicing to Face the Iraq Insurgency
articles.snippet: Three years into the conflict in Iraq, the front line in the American drive to prepare troops for insurgent warfare runs through a cluster of mock Iraqi villages deep in the Mojave Desert, nearly 10,000 miles from the realities awaiting the soldie...
articles.abstract: Three years into the conflict in Iraq, the front line in the American drive to prepare troops for insurgent warfare runs through a cluster of mock Iraqi villages deep in the Mojave Desert, nearly 10,000 miles from the realities awaiting the soldiers outside Baghdad and Mosul and Falluja.     Out here, 150 miles northeast of Los Angeles, units of the 10th Mountain Division from Fort Drum, N.Y., are among the latest war-bound troops who have gone through three weeks of training that introduce them to the harsh episodes that characterize the American experience in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT IRWIN, Calif. - Three years into the conflict in Iraq, the front line in the American drive to prepare troops for insurgent warfare runs through a cluster of mock Iraqi villages deep in the Mojave Desert, nearly 10,000 miles from the realities awaiting the soldiers outside Baghdad and Mosul and Falluja.
articles.byline: By Dexter Filkins and John F. Burns

articles.headline: Sharp Reaction To G.O.P. Plan On Gas Rebate
articles.snippet: The Senate Republican plan to mail $100 checks to voters to ease the burden of high gasoline prices is eliciting more scorn than gratitude from the very people it was intended to help.      Aides for several Republican senators reported a surge of...
articles.abstract: The Senate Republican plan to mail $100 checks to voters to ease the burden of high gasoline prices is eliciting more scorn than gratitude from the very people it was intended to help.      Aides for several Republican senators reported a surge of calls and e-mail messages from constituents ridiculing the rebate as a paltry and transparent effort to pander to voters before the midterm elections in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 30 - The Senate Republican plan to mail $100 checks to voters to ease the burden of high gasoline prices is eliciting more scorn than gratitude from the very people it was intended to help.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Next Step for Counterfeiters: Faking the Whole Company
articles.snippet: At first it seemed to be nothing more than a routine case of counterfeiting in a country where faking it has become an industry.     In mid-2004, managers at the Tokyo headquarters of the Japanese electronics giant NEC started receiving reports th...
articles.abstract: At first it seemed to be nothing more than a routine case of counterfeiting in a country where faking it has become an industry.     In mid-2004, managers at the Tokyo headquarters of the Japanese electronics giant NEC started receiving reports that pirated keyboards and blank CD and DVD discs bearing the company's brand were on sale in retail outlets in Beijing and Hong Kong. So like many other manufacturers combating intellectual property thieves in China, the company hired an investigator to track down the pirates.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING - At first it seemed to be nothing more than a routine case of counterfeiting in a country where faking it has become an industry.

articles.headline: Some See Hints Of Disharmony In Qaeda Tapes
articles.snippet: The broadcasts last week by three of the world's best-known terrorist leaders shared at least one common goal, American intelligence officials say. They sought to embarrass the West by showing that the terrorists were still able to communicate wit...
articles.abstract: The broadcasts last week by three of the world's best-known terrorist leaders shared at least one common goal, American intelligence officials say. They sought to embarrass the West by showing that the terrorists were still able to communicate with their followers, despite the intensive efforts to capture or kill them and the $25 million bounty that is on each of their heads.      But the officials interviewed on Sunday also said that the messages of the three men -- Osama bin Laden, Ayman al-Zawahiri and Abu Musab al-Zarqawi -- show the differing motives and political interests of Al Qaeda's leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 30 - The broadcasts last week by three of the world's best-known terrorist leaders shared at least one common goal, American intelligence officials say. They sought to embarrass the West by showing that the terrorists were still able to communicate with their followers, despite the intensive efforts to capture or kill them and the $25 million bounty that is on each of their heads.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: DEADLINE PASSES WITHOUT ACCORD IN DARFUR TALKS
articles.snippet: Sudan's government offered Sunday to accept a potentially historic Darfur peace agreement, but two of Darfur's three main rebel groups raised last-minute objections that left the negotiations mired in confusion as a midnight deadline passed. Media...
articles.abstract: Sudan's government offered Sunday to accept a potentially historic Darfur peace agreement, but two of Darfur's three main rebel groups raised last-minute objections that left the negotiations mired in confusion as a midnight deadline passed. Mediators agreed to extend the talks for 48 hours at the request of the United States.     It was unclear early Monday whether the extension in the feverish negotiations, supervised by the African Union at talks in Abuja, Nigeria, made it more or less likely that a deal could be reached. The talks are the most intensive yet in an effort to end the strife in Darfur, the vast region of western Sudan that is the site of what the United Nations has called the world's worst refugee crisis and what the Bush administration calls genocide.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan, Monday, May 1 - Sudan's government offered Sunday to accept a potentially historic Darfur peace agreement, but two of Darfur's three main rebel groups raised last-minute objections that left the negotiations mired in confusion as a midnight deadline passed. Mediators agreed to extend the talks for 48 hours at the request of the United States.
articles.byline: By Lydia Polgreen and Joel Brinkley

articles.headline: A Studio Chief's Jailhouse Visits to a Detective Raise Questions
articles.snippet: Two days before Christmas 2004, as Hollywood's A-listers were jetting to places like Aspen and Kona, Ron Meyer, the president of Universal Studios, made a trip to a decidedly less glamorous destination.     Mr. Meyer got in his Range Rover and dro...
articles.abstract: Two days before Christmas 2004, as Hollywood's A-listers were jetting to places like Aspen and Kona, Ron Meyer, the president of Universal Studios, made a trip to a decidedly less glamorous destination.     Mr. Meyer got in his Range Rover and drove more than 120 miles north from his home here to Taft, Calif., to visit Anthony Pellicano, the imprisoned private investigator.
articles.lead_paragraph: MALIBU, Calif., April 29 - Two days before Christmas 2004, as Hollywood's A-listers were jetting to places like Aspen and Kona, Ron Meyer, the president of Universal Studios, made a trip to a decidedly less glamorous destination.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Allison Hope Weiner

articles.headline: Duke's Struggling Cousin Rises From Its Shadow
articles.snippet: North Carolina Central University does not have a lacrosse team. Students often cannot check out books from the main library, which is being renovated after a mold infestation. The business school is fighting to regain accreditation. Sixty percent...
articles.abstract: North Carolina Central University does not have a lacrosse team. Students often cannot check out books from the main library, which is being renovated after a mold infestation. The business school is fighting to regain accreditation. Sixty percent of the students receive need-based financial aid. Eighty-one percent are black. Only 28 percent graduate after four years.     Just three miles from Duke University and its master-planned marriage of Gothic elegance and academic excellence, North Carolina Central, a rambling red-brick, historically black institution, is across the tracks, across the highway, across an immeasurable cultural divide. Or so goes the armchair anthropology.
articles.lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C., April 30 - North Carolina Central University does not have a lacrosse team. Students often cannot check out books from the main library, which is being renovated after a mold infestation. The business school is fighting to regain accreditation. Sixty percent of the students receive need-based financial aid. Eighty-one percent are black. Only 28 percent graduate after four years.

articles.headline: New Microsoft Browser Raises Google's Hackles
articles.snippet: With a $10 billion advertising market at stake, Google, the fast-rising Internet star, is raising objections to the way that it says Microsoft, the incumbent powerhouse of computing, is wielding control over Internet searching in its new Web brows...
articles.abstract: With a $10 billion advertising market at stake, Google, the fast-rising Internet star, is raising objections to the way that it says Microsoft, the incumbent powerhouse of computing, is wielding control over Internet searching in its new Web browser.      Google, which only recently began beefing up its lobbying efforts in Washington, says it expressed concerns about competition in the Web search business in recent talks with the Justice Department and the European Commission, both of which have brought previous antitrust actions against Microsoft.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a $10 billion advertising market at stake, Google, the fast-rising Internet star, is raising objections to the way that it says Microsoft, the incumbent powerhouse of computing, is wielding control over Internet searching in its new Web browser.

articles.headline: Reality And Fantasy, Indivisible
articles.snippet: THIS year's Tribeca Film Festival opened with ''United 93,'' a fictional account of real but mostly unknowable events. The feature film examines the last hour in the lives of the only group of Americans who were able to alter the events of Sept. 1...
articles.abstract: THIS year's Tribeca Film Festival opened with ''United 93,'' a fictional account of real but mostly unknowable events. The feature film examines the last hour in the lives of the only group of Americans who were able to alter the events of Sept. 11.      In that crucible, heroes were born, legends were made and a catchphrase -- ''Let's roll'' -- was christened. The film's attempt to discern what ''really happened'' landed with tremendous impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: THIS year's Tribeca Film Festival opened with "United 93," a fictional account of real but mostly unknowable events. The feature film examines the last hour in the lives of the only group of Americans who were able to alter the events of Sept. 11.

articles.headline: Guess Who's Got His Back?
articles.snippet: Article on partnership program that Sam's Club division of Wal-Mart has created to help small businesses survive and thrive; services for Sam's Club members who own small businesses include exclusive hours, designated online ordering system, low-c...
articles.abstract: Article on partnership program that Sam's Club division of Wal-Mart has created to help small businesses survive and thrive; services for Sam's Club members who own small businesses include exclusive hours, designated online ordering system, low-cost Web site setups, waiver of fees for its health plans and help with financial services; photos (special section, Small Business) (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: RIGHT or wrong, it has somehow become conventional wisdom: Wal-Mart is bad for small businesses, outspending, outmaneuvering and outgrowing lesser rivals until they change their strategy or close their doors.

articles.headline: A Small Step At Starbucks From Mocha To Movies
articles.snippet: With barely one movie under its belt, Starbucks is moving aggressively toward expanding its involvement in the entertainment business, seeking movies and books to promote in the hope of duplicating the success it has had with music.      The retai...
articles.abstract: With barely one movie under its belt, Starbucks is moving aggressively toward expanding its involvement in the entertainment business, seeking movies and books to promote in the hope of duplicating the success it has had with music.      The retail coffee giant -- which used its stores to promote ''Akeelah and the Bee,'' a Lionsgate movie that opened this weekend -- is to announce Monday that it has signed an agreement with the William Morris Agency to find more movie and book projects to market. The aim is to have one book in Starbucks stores this year, and at least two or three movies to promote and sell on DVD next year, with more projects in years to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, April 30 - With barely one movie under its belt, Starbucks is moving aggressively toward expanding its involvement in the entertainment business, seeking movies and books to promote in the hope of duplicating the success it has had with music.

articles.headline: The Rise and Fall Of Revolution
articles.snippet: For more than a year, Joe Roth has been hearing the Hollywood gossips predict the demise of his six-year-old movie studio, Revolution Studios. Now that they are right, he wants to set the record straight.     His version goes something like this: ...
articles.abstract: For more than a year, Joe Roth has been hearing the Hollywood gossips predict the demise of his six-year-old movie studio, Revolution Studios. Now that they are right, he wants to set the record straight.     His version goes something like this: In 2000, Mr. Roth, who ran not one but two major Hollywood studios, announced with fanfare that he would start an independent studio that would create quality movies with modest budgets. He brought in investors, most notably Sony Pictures Entertainment, to share the cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, April 29 - For more than a year, Joe Roth has been hearing the Hollywood gossips predict the demise of his six-year-old movie studio, Revolution Studios. Now that they are right, he wants to set the record straight.
